q1.question: What do I get for $9.99?
q1.answer: You receive a complete PID tuning analysis including optimized PID values, filter settings, feedforward configuration, and ready-to-use CLI commands. Results are delivered instantly and also sent to your email.

q2.question: Do I need to pay before seeing results?
q2.answer: You can upload your blackbox log and go through the analysis setup for free. Payment is only required to view the final optimized settings.

q3.question: What if I'm not satisfied?
q3.answer: We offer a satisfaction guarantee. If the tune doesn't work for your setup, contact us for a full refund.

HomePage.title: FPVTune
HomePage.description: Neural network-powered FPV drone PID tuning and configuration optimization assistant

landing.heroDesc: Upload your Betaflight blackbox logs and get optimized PID settings in seconds. Our neural network analyzes gyro noise, identifies resonance frequencies, and generates the perfect tune for your FPV drone.

whatIsPid.title: What is Betaflight PID Tuning?
whatIsPid.desc1: is the process of adjusting your flight controller's Proportional, Integral, and Derivative gains to achieve optimal flight performance. Proper PID tuning eliminates oscillations, reduces prop wash, and makes your FPV drone feel locked-in and responsive.
whatIsPid.desc2: Traditional PID tuning requires hours of test flights, analyzing blackbox logs manually, and making incremental adjustments. Most pilots struggle with understanding gyro noise patterns, filter settings, and the complex relationship between P, I, and D gains.
whatIsPid.desc3: to automate this entire process. Our neural network has been trained on thousands of blackbox logs from various drone configurations, learning the optimal PID settings for different frame sizes, motor combinations, and flying styles.

problems.title: Common PID Tuning Problems
problems.propWashDesc: Vibrations during quick descents or sharp turns caused by turbulent air hitting the propellers.
problems.hotMotorsDesc: Excessive D-gain or inadequate filtering causes motors to overheat and reduces their lifespan.
problems.sluggishDesc: Low P-gains result in slow, mushy stick response that makes precise flying difficult.
problems.midThrottleDesc: Vibrations at certain throttle positions due to motor resonance frequencies.

howItWorksSection.title: How Neural Network-Powered Analysis Works
howItWorksSection.desc: FPVtune analyzes your blackbox data using advanced neural networks to generate optimized settings tailored to your specific drone configuration.
howItWorksSection.step1Desc: Record a short flight with blackbox logging enabled in Betaflight Configurator. Upload the .BBL or .BFL file to FPVtune. We support Betaflight 4.5 and newer log formats.
howItWorksSection.step2Desc: Our neural network performs spectral analysis on your gyro data, identifies noise frequencies, measures step response, and evaluates your current PID performance against thousands of reference tunes.
howItWorksSection.step3Desc: Receive optimized PID values, filter settings, and feedforward gains. Copy the generated CLI commands directly into Betaflight Configurator and enjoy a perfectly tuned FPV drone.

featuresSection.title: Advanced Analysis Features
featuresSection.desc: Everything you need to achieve the perfect tune for your FPV drone, from noise analysis to thermal prediction.
featuresSection.spectralDesc: Visualizes gyro noise and D-term resonance across the frequency spectrum. Our neural network identifies the exact frequencies where dynamic notch filters should be placed for optimal noise reduction without adding latency.
featuresSection.cliExportDesc: Generate Betaflight CLI commands instantly. Copy and paste directly into your flight controller for immediate results.
featuresSection.thermalDesc: Aggressive PID tuning can overheat motors. Our neural network predicts motor temperature based on your noise profile and recommends safe D-gain limits to protect your hardware.
featuresSection.dynamicFilterDesc: Automatically configure gyro lowpass, D-term lowpass, and dynamic notch filters. Minimize filtering delay while maintaining clean motor signals for the smoothest possible flight.
featuresSection.propWashElimDesc: Our neural network optimizes D_min, D_max, and feedforward settings specifically to eliminate prop wash oscillation during aggressive maneuvers and quick descents.

supported.title: PID Tuning for Every FPV Drone
supported.desc: Whether you fly a tiny whoop, 5-inch freestyle quad, or 7-inch long range build, FPVtune delivers optimized Betaflight PID settings for your specific configuration.
supported.escProtocolsDesc: Compatible with DShot150, DShot300, DShot600, and bidirectional DShot for RPM filtering.
supported.gyroChipDesc: Works with MPU6000, ICM20689, ICM42688, BMI270, and all other common gyroscopes.
supported.flyingStyleDesc: Optimized profiles for freestyle, racing, cinematic, and long-range flying styles.

whyChoose.title: Why Choose FPVtune?
whyChoose.desc: Stop guessing and start flying with confidence. Our neural network-powered approach delivers consistent, reliable results that traditional methods cannot match.

guide.title: Complete Betaflight PID Tuning Guide
guide.desc: Master the fundamentals of Betaflight PID tuning and understand how each parameter affects your drone's flight characteristics.
guide.pGain: Understanding P Gain in Betaflight PID Tuning
guide.pGainDesc: The Proportional gain determines how aggressively your drone corrects errors. Higher P values make the quad more responsive but can cause oscillations. In Betaflight PID tuning, finding the right P gain is crucial for achieving crisp stick response without introducing vibrations.
guide.iGain: The Role of I Gain in Betaflight PID Tuning
guide.iGainDesc: Integral gain helps your drone maintain attitude against external forces like wind. During Betaflight PID tuning, proper I gain settings ensure your quad holds its position without drifting. Too much I gain causes slow oscillations, while too little results in poor hover stability.
guide.dGain: D Gain Optimization in Betaflight PID Tuning
guide.dGainDesc: Derivative gain dampens oscillations and reduces prop wash. Effective Betaflight PID tuning requires careful D gain adjustment to eliminate bounce-back without overheating motors. FPVtune analyzes your noise profile to recommend optimal D values for your specific setup.
guide.filter: Filter Settings in Betaflight PID Tuning
guide.filterDesc: Proper filter configuration is essential for successful Betaflight PID tuning. Gyro and D-term lowpass filters remove noise that can cause motor heating. Dynamic notch filters target specific resonance frequencies. FPVtune automatically calculates optimal filter cutoffs based on your blackbox data.
guide.feedforward: Feedforward in Modern Betaflight PID Tuning
guide.feedforwardDesc: Feedforward anticipates stick movements for instant response. Advanced Betaflight PID tuning includes feedforward optimization to reduce latency and improve stick feel. Our neural network analyzes your flying style to recommend feedforward values that match your preferences.
guide.rpm: RPM Filtering and Betaflight PID Tuning
guide.rpmDesc: Bidirectional DShot enables RPM-based filtering for cleaner motor signals. When performing Betaflight PID tuning with RPM filtering, you can run higher PID gains with less filtering delay. FPVtune detects RPM filter status and adjusts recommendations accordingly.

faq.title: Betaflight PID Tuning FAQ
faq.desc: Common questions about Betaflight PID tuning and how FPVtune can help you achieve the perfect tune.
faq.q1: What is the best way to start Betaflight PID tuning?
faq.a1: The best approach to Betaflight PID tuning is to start with a clean blackbox log from a hover and light maneuvers. Upload this log to FPVtune for smart analysis. Our system will identify noise patterns and generate optimized PID settings as a starting point for your tune.
faq.q2: How long does Betaflight PID tuning usually take?
faq.a2: Traditional Betaflight PID tuning can take hours or even days of test flights and adjustments. With FPVtune, you can get optimized PID settings in under 30 seconds. Simply upload your blackbox log and receive instant recommendations tailored to your drone.
faq.q3: Can FPVtune help with Betaflight PID tuning for racing drones?
faq.a3: Yes, FPVtune supports Betaflight PID tuning for all drone types including racing quads. Our neural network has been trained on thousands of racing drone logs and understands the specific requirements for low-latency, high-response tunes that competitive pilots need.
faq.q4: Do I need experience with Betaflight PID tuning to use FPVtune?
faq.a4: No prior Betaflight PID tuning experience is required. FPVtune is designed for pilots of all skill levels. Our neural network handles the complex analysis and provides ready-to-use CLI commands. Just copy and paste into Betaflight Configurator to apply your optimized tune.
faq.q5: What Betaflight versions are supported for PID tuning?
faq.a5: FPVtune supports Betaflight PID tuning for versions 4.3, 4.4, and 4.5. Our neural network understands the differences between firmware versions and generates appropriate settings for your specific Betaflight installation. We regularly update our models to support the latest Betaflight releases.

faq.title: FAQ
faq.description: Common questions about neural network tuning

q1.question: What files do I need to upload?
q1.answer: Blackbox log files (.bbl/.bfl) for flight data analysis, CLI dump for current config. Recommend recording 30+ seconds of normal flight.

q2.question: How long does neural network analysis take?
q2.answer: Usually completes within 1-2 minutes. Complex log files may take longer, you'll be notified by email when done.

q3.question: Which flight controller firmware is supported?
q3.answer: Currently supports Betaflight 4.5+, INAV 6.0+ and EmuFlight. KISS and other firmware support is in development.

q4.question: Can I use the generated parameters directly?
q4.answer: Neural network-generated parameters are an optimized starting point based on your data. Recommend test flying in a safe environment and fine-tuning based on feel.

q5.question: Is my data secure?
q5.answer: Your flight data is only used for analysis and won't be stored or shared. Data is automatically deleted after analysis.

meta.title: How to Export Blackbox Logs - FPVTune
meta.description: Detailed tutorial: How to export Blackbox flight log files from Betaflight flight controller

exportBlackbox.title: How to Export Blackbox Logs
exportBlackbox.description: Learn how to export Blackbox flight log files from your flight controller for analysis

intro.title: Why Export Blackbox Logs?
intro.p1: Blackbox logs record all critical data from your drone during flight, including gyro readings, PID control outputs, motor speeds, and more. By analyzing this data, you can:

benefits.tune: Optimize PID parameters to improve flight performance
benefits.diagnose: Diagnose flight issues like oscillations and propwash
benefits.improve: Understand flight characteristics and improve piloting skills

intro.p2: This tutorial will teach you how to quickly export Blackbox log files. The entire process takes only 5 minutes.

software.title: Required Software
software.description: Download and install Betaflight Configurator (official configuration tool)
software.link: Visit betaflight.com to download the latest version

hardware.title: Check Flight Controller Configuration
hardware.storage: Confirm your flight controller has an SD card slot or onboard flash
hardware.enabled: Enable Blackbox recording in Betaflight configuration
hardware.space: Ensure sufficient storage space (recommend at least 100MB)

cable.title: Prepare Connection Cable
cable.description: Prepare a USB data cable (Micro-USB or USB-C, depending on your flight controller)

what.title: What is a Blackbox Log?
what.description: Blackbox logs are detailed flight data recorded by the flight controller, including gyro, accelerometer, motor outputs, and more. This data is crucial for analyzing flight performance and tuning PID parameters.

1.title: Connect Flight Controller to Betaflight Configurator
1.description: Connect your flight controller to your computer using a USB cable, open Betaflight Configurator and click the Connect button.
1.imageAlt: Connect flight controller to Betaflight Configurator

2.title: Export Log Files
2.description: Choose the export method based on your storage type:

sdCard.title: SD Card Storage
sdCard.description: If using SD card, directly copy .bbl or .bfl files from the card

onboard.title: Onboard Flash
onboard.description: If using onboard flash, click Save Flash to File button to export

recording.title: Record High-Quality Logs
recording.duration: Recording duration: Recommend 30-60 seconds of flight data including hover, forward flight, and basic maneuvers
recording.conditions: Flight conditions: Choose calm or light wind weather to avoid extreme conditions affecting data quality
recording.maneuvers: Flight maneuvers: Include different throttle positions, turns, and pitch movements for comprehensive flight characteristics

storage.title: Storage Management
storage.sdCard: SD card: Recommend high-speed SD cards (Class 10 or UHS-I) to avoid write delays
storage.space: Space management: Regularly clean old logs, maintain at least 200MB free space
storage.backup: Data backup: Back up important flight logs to computer to avoid accidental loss

analysis.title: Analysis Preparation
analysis.naming: File naming: Use meaningful filenames like "5inch_freestyle_20260113.bbl"
analysis.notes: Flight notes: Record issues and feelings during flight to help AI analyze more accurately
analysis.multiple: Multiple flights: If issues are inconsistent, upload multiple logs for comparison

nextSteps.title: Next Steps
nextSteps.description: After successfully exporting Blackbox logs, you can:

upload.title: Upload to FPVTune for AI Analysis
upload.description: Let AI analyze your flight data, identify issues, and generate optimized PID settings

viewer.title: View with Blackbox Explorer
viewer.description: Official Betaflight tool to visualize flight data and waveforms

learn.title: Learn PID Tuning Basics
learn.description: Understand PID parameter meanings and tuning principles to improve flying skills

q1.question: Why is there no Blackbox data?
q1.answer: First check if Blackbox recording is enabled in flight controller configuration. Go to Blackbox tab in Betaflight Configurator and ensure recording is enabled. Second, check if storage media (SD card or onboard flash) has sufficient space. If using SD card, ensure it's properly inserted and formatted as FAT32.

q2.question: File too large to upload?
q2.answer: FPVTune supports log files up to 50MB. If file is too large, use Blackbox Explorer to open the log and export only the time segment you need to analyze. Or record shorter flights (30-60 seconds is sufficient) to avoid large files from long recordings.

q3.question: Which flight controller firmware is supported?
q3.answer: FPVTune supports Blackbox logs from Betaflight 4.0+, INAV 2.0+, EmuFlight, and other mainstream firmware. Different firmware have slightly different log formats, but all can be correctly recognized and analyzed.

q4.question: SD card read failure?
q4.answer: If SD card cannot be read, try: 1) Re-insert SD card; 2) Format as FAT32 on computer; 3) Replace with high-quality SD card (recommend SanDisk or Samsung); 4) Check if flight controller SD card slot has dust or damage.

q5.question: Onboard flash export is slow?
q5.answer: Onboard flash read speed is usually slower than SD card, this is normal. Export may take several minutes, please be patient. If you frequently need to export logs, recommend using SD card storage for faster read speeds and larger capacity.

q6.question: Log file corrupted and won't open?
q6.answer: Log corruption usually occurs due to power loss during flight or storage media failure. Try using Blackbox Explorer's repair function, or re-record a complete flight. To avoid corruption, wait a few seconds after flight ends before powering off to let data fully write.

meta.title: How to Export CLI Dump - FPVTune
meta.description: Detailed tutorial: How to export CLI configuration files from Betaflight flight controller

exportCliDump.title: How to Export CLI Dump
exportCliDump.description: Learn how to export CLI configuration files from your flight controller for analysis

intro.title: Why Export CLI Dump?
intro.p1: CLI Dump is a complete snapshot of your flight controller configuration. It contains all settings including PID values, filter configurations, rates, motor mapping, and more. Having a CLI dump allows you to:

benefits.backup: Backup your configuration before making changes
benefits.restore: Quickly restore settings if something goes wrong
benefits.share: Share your configuration with others or get help from the community
benefits.analyze: Let AI analyze your settings and suggest improvements

intro.p2: This tutorial will show you how to export a CLI dump in just a few minutes.

software.title: Required Software
software.description: Download and install Betaflight Configurator (official configuration tool)
software.link: Visit betaflight.com to download the latest version

connection.title: Connection Requirements
connection.cable: Prepare a USB data cable (Micro-USB or USB-C)
connection.driver: Ensure proper USB drivers are installed
connection.battery: Flight controller can be powered via USB or battery

what.title: What is a CLI Dump?
what.description: CLI Dump is a complete configuration export from your flight controller, including all settings, PID values, filter configurations, and more. This file can be used for backing up your configuration or having AI analyze your settings.

1.title: Connect Flight Controller to Betaflight Configurator
1.description: Connect your flight controller to your computer using a USB cable, open Betaflight Configurator and click the Connect button.
1.imageAlt: Connect flight controller to Betaflight Configurator

2.title: Navigate to CLI Tab
2.description: In Betaflight Configurator, click on the CLI tab in the left menu.

3.title: Execute dump Command
3.description: Type the following command in the CLI command line and press Enter:
3.note: Wait for the command to complete, which usually takes a few seconds.

4.title: Save Output to File
4.description: Save the CLI output to a text file:
4.step1: Select all CLI output (Ctrl+A or Cmd+A)
4.step3: Paste into a text editor and save as .txt file

tip.title: Tip:
tip.description: Use a meaningful filename like JHEF745V2_20260113.txt including the flight controller model and date.

backup.title: Regular Configuration Backups
backup.frequency: Backup frequency: Export CLI dump after every important settings change
backup.naming: Naming convention: Use date and version numbers like "config_v2.3_20260113.txt"
backup.storage: Storage location: Save to cloud storage or multiple locations to avoid data loss

documentation.title: Document Configuration Changes
documentation.notes: Change notes: Add comments at the beginning of file explaining what was changed and why
documentation.comparison: Version comparison: Keep multiple configuration versions for easy comparison and rollback
documentation.testing: Test records: Record flight performance for each configuration version for optimization

sharing.title: Sharing Configurations
sharing.community: Community exchange: Share configurations with FPV community to get advice from other pilots
sharing.privacy: Privacy protection: Check for sensitive information (like GPS coordinates) before sharing
sharing.format: Format cleanup: Use text editor to organize format for better readability

nextSteps.title: Next Steps
nextSteps.description: After successfully exporting CLI dump, you can:

upload.title: Use with Blackbox Logs
upload.description: Upload CLI dump together with Blackbox logs to FPVTune for more accurate analysis

compare.title: Compare Different Configurations
compare.description: Use text comparison tools (like WinMerge) to compare differences between configuration versions

restore.title: Restore Configuration
restore.description: If tuning goes wrong, use backed up CLI dump to quickly restore to previous state

q1.question: CLI command not responding?
q1.answer: First ensure flight controller is properly connected to computer with good USB cable contact. If still not responding, try: 1) Disconnect and reconnect flight controller; 2) Restart Betaflight Configurator; 3) Change USB port or cable; 4) Check if drivers are correctly installed.

q2.question: Incomplete dump output?
q2.answer: The dump command takes a few seconds to fully execute, please wait patiently until command prompt appears again. If output is interrupted, it may be unstable USB connection, try using better quality cable. Ensure not to operate flight controller or move USB cable during command execution.

q3.question: Can I save directly in CLI?
q3.answer: Betaflight Configurator 10.8.0 and above supports "Save to File" button that can directly save CLI output as text file without manual copy-paste. If your version is older, recommend upgrading to latest version for better experience.

q4.question: How to restore CLI dump configuration?
q4.answer: Restoring configuration is simple: 1) Connect flight controller and go to CLI tab; 2) Open saved CLI dump file; 3) Copy all content (skip comment lines); 4) Paste into CLI command line; 5) Type "save" to save settings. Note: Recommend backing up current configuration before restoring.

q5.question: What information does CLI dump contain?
q5.answer: CLI dump contains complete flight controller configuration including: PID parameters, filter settings, rate curves, motor mapping, receiver configuration, OSD settings, mode switches, etc. Basically all parameters that can be set in Betaflight Configurator are exported.

q6.question: Are dumps from different firmware versions compatible?
q6.answer: Different Betaflight versions may have parameter changes, directly restoring old version dumps may cause some settings to be invalid or incorrect. Recommend reconfiguring after firmware upgrade, or use diff command to export only settings different from defaults for better compatibility.
